comment_text.mn34:1.2: The Buddha also gave a discourse here shortly after the deaths of Sāriputta and Moggallāna (SN 47.14:1.1).
comment_text.mn34:2.1: Thus illustrating the need to “know the ford” in the previous sutta (MN 33:2.3). | The Suvidehans are not mentioned anywhere else, and the commentary simply treats them as Videhans. But Videha lay to the north-east of Vajjī, and since the expansion of Vajjī and contraction of Videha before the Buddha’s time, it is unlikely that it bordered the Ganges opposite Magadha. Perhaps this story stems from a time when Videha did expand to the river, or perhaps there were folks who called themselves “good Videhans” after the eclipse of the kingdom.
comment_text.mn34:5.9: Typically bhūtapubbaṁ is used for fables (“once upon a time”), but see also MN 36:4.3.
comment_text.mn34:12.2: While commonly found elsewhere, this tag line is only used three times in the Majjhima Nikāya (MN 130:30.2, MN 142:14.2).
comment_text.mn34:12.3: This echoes Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.7.1 (ayaṁ ca lokaḥ paraśca lokaḥ).

root_text.mn34:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā vajjīsu viharati ukkacelāyaṁ gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre.
root_text.mn34:2.1: “Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, māgadhako gopālako duppaññajātiko, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye, asamavekkhitvā gaṅgāya nadiyā orimaṁ tīraṁ, asamavekkhitvā pārimaṁ tīraṁ, atittheneva gāvo patāresi uttaraṁ tīraṁ suvidehānaṁ.
root_text.mn34:3.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, gāvo majjhegaṅgāya nadiyā sote āmaṇḍaliyaṁ karitvā tattheva anayabyasanaṁ āpajjiṁsu.
root_text.mn34:3.3: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, māgadhako gopālako duppaññajātiko, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye, asamavekkhitvā gaṅgāya nadiyā orimaṁ tīraṁ, asamavekkhitvā pārimaṁ tīraṁ, atittheneva gāvo patāresi uttaraṁ tīraṁ suvidehānaṁ.
root_text.mn34:3.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā akusalā imassa lokassa akusalā parassa lokassa, akusalā māradheyyassa akusalā amāradheyyassa, akusalā maccudheyyassa akusalā amaccudheyyassa, tesaṁ ye sotabbaṁ saddahātabbaṁ maññissanti, tesaṁ taṁ bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya.
root_text.mn34:4.1: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, māgadhako gopālako sappaññajātiko, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye, samavekkhitvā gaṅgāya nadiyā orimaṁ tīraṁ, samavekkhitvā pārimaṁ tīraṁ, tittheneva gāvo patāresi uttaraṁ tīraṁ suvidehānaṁ.
root_text.mn34:5.1: So paṭhamaṁ patāresi ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā.
root_text.mn34:5.2: Te tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu.
root_text.mn34:5.4: Tepi tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu.
root_text.mn34:5.6: Tepi tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu.
root_text.mn34:5.8: Tepi tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu.
root_text.mn34:5.9: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, vacchako taruṇako tāvadeva jātako mātugoravakena vuyhamāno, sopi tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamāsi.
root_text.mn34:5.11: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, māgadhako gopālako sappaññajātiko, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye, samavekkhitvā gaṅgāya nadiyā orimaṁ tīraṁ, samavekkhitvā pārimaṁ tīraṁ, tittheneva gāvo patāresi uttaraṁ tīraṁ suvidehānaṁ.
root_text.mn34:5.12: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kusalā imassa lokassa kusalā parassa lokassa, kusalā māradheyyassa kusalā amāradheyyassa, kusalā maccudheyyassa kusalā amaccudheyyassa, tesaṁ ye sotabbaṁ saddahātabbaṁ maññissanti, tesaṁ taṁ bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn34:6.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu;
root_text.mn34:6.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, te tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṅgatā.
root_text.mn34:7.1: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, balavagāvo dammagāvo tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu;
root_text.mn34:7.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā, tepi tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gamissanti.
root_text.mn34:8.1: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, vacchatarā vacchatariyo tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu;
root_text.mn34:8.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti, tepi tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gamissanti.
root_text.mn34:9.1: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, vacchakā kisābalakā tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamaṁsu;
root_text.mn34:9.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyanā, tepi tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gamissanti.
root_text.mn34:10.1: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, vacchako taruṇako tāvadeva jātako mātugoravakena vuyhamāno tiriyaṁ gaṅgāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ agamāsi;
root_text.mn34:10.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū dhammānusārino saddhānusārino, tepi tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gamissanti.
root_text.mn34:11.1: Ahaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, kusalo imassa lokassa kusalo parassa lokassa, kusalo māradheyyassa kusalo amāradheyyassa, kusalo maccudheyyassa kusalo amaccudheyyassa. Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, ye sotabbaṁ saddahātabbaṁ maññissanti, tesaṁ taṁ bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.mn34:12.2: Idaṁ vatvā sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:

translation_text.mn34:0.2: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd
translation_text.mn34:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river.
translation_text.mn34:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn34:2.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an unintelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, without inspecting the near shore or the far shore, he drove his cattle across a place with no ford on the Ganges river to the northern shore among the Suvidehans.
translation_text.mn34:3.1: But the cattle bunched up in mid-stream and came to ruin right there.
translation_text.mn34:3.3: Because the unintelligent cowherd failed to inspect the shores before driving the cattle across at a place with no ford.
translation_text.mn34:3.4: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are unskilled in this world and the other world, unskilled in Māra’s dominion and its opposite, and unskilled in Death’s dominion and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting harm and suffering.
translation_text.mn34:4.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an intelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, after inspecting the near shore and the far shore, he drove his cattle across a ford on the Ganges river to the northern shore among the Suvidehans.
translation_text.mn34:5.1: First he drove across the bulls, the fathers and captains of the herd.
translation_text.mn34:5.2: They breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:5.3: Then he drove across the strong and tractable cattle.
translation_text.mn34:5.4: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:5.5: Then he drove across the bullocks and heifers.
translation_text.mn34:5.6: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:5.7: Then he drove across the calves and weak cattle.
translation_text.mn34:5.8: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:5.9: Once it happened that a baby calf had just been born. Urged on by its mother’s lowing, even it managed to breast the stream of the Ganges and safely reach the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:5.11: Because the intelligent cowherd inspected both shores before driving the cattle across at a ford.
translation_text.mn34:5.12: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are skilled in this world and the other world, skilled in Māra’s dominion and its opposite, and skilled in Death’s dominion and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn34:6.1: Just like the bulls, fathers and captains of the herd, who crossed the Ganges to safety
translation_text.mn34:6.2: are the mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. Having breasted Māra’s stream, they have safely crossed over to the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:7.1: Just like the strong and tractable cattle who crossed the Ganges to safety
translation_text.mn34:7.2: are the mendicants who, with the ending of the five lower fetters, are reborn spontaneously. They’re extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:8.1: Just like the bullocks and heifers who crossed the Ganges to safety
translation_text.mn34:8.2: are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:9.1: Just like the calves and weak cattle who crossed the Ganges to safety
translation_text.mn34:9.2: are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:10.1: Just like the baby calf who had just been born, but, urged on by its mother’s lowing, still managed to cross the Ganges to safety
translation_text.mn34:10.2: are the mendicants who are followers of teachings, followers by faith. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
translation_text.mn34:11.1: Mendicants, I am skilled in this world and the other world, skilled in Māra’s dominion and its opposite, and skilled in Death’s dominion and its opposite. If anyone thinks I am worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.mn34:12.1: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn34:12.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.mn34:12.4: have been clearly explained by one who knows;
translation_text.mn34:12.6: and what’s out of Death’s reach.
translation_text.mn34:12.9: has opened the door to freedom from death,
translation_text.mn34:12.11: The Wicked One’s stream has been cut,
translation_text.mn34:12.12: it’s blown away and mown down.
